title: Anberlin
text:
{{Short description|American alternative rock band}}
{{Use mdy dates|date=April 2021}}
{{Infobox musical artist
| name            = Anberlin
| image           = Anberlin_HK_2011.jpg
| caption         = Anberlin performing in Hong Kong, 2011
| origin          = [[Winter Haven, Florida|Winter Haven]], [[Florida]], U.S.
| genre           = [[Alternative rock]], [[emo]]<ref name="AM-emo">{{cite web|last1=Collar|first1=Matt|title=Vital - Anberlin|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/vital-mw0002420745|publisher=[[AllMusic]]|access-date=June 30, 2016|quote=Although Anberlin have never shied away from angular sounds, much of the band's previous work revealed a mix of sparkling, U2-style uplift and plaintive, [[Paramore]]-style emo.}}</ref>
| years_active    = 2002–2014, 2018, 2019–present
| label           = {{hlist|[[Universal Republic Records|Universal Republic]]|[[Island Records|Island UK]]|[[Tooth & Nail Records|Tooth & Nail]]|[[UNFD]]|Big3|[[Equal Vision Records|Equal Vision]]}}
| associated_acts = [[Acceptance (band)|Acceptance]], SaGoh 24/7
| website         = {{URL|http://www.anberlin.com/}}
| current_members = *[[Stephen Christian]]
*Deon Rexroat
*Joseph Milligan
*Nathan Young
*Christian McAlhaney
| past_members    = *Joey Bruce 
*Nathan Strayer
}}
'''Anberlin''' is an American [[alternative rock]] band formed in [[Winter Haven, Florida]] in 2002. Since the beginning of 2007, the band consists of lead vocalist [[Stephen Christian]], guitarists Joseph Milligan and Christian McAlhaney, bassist Deon Rexroat, and drummer Nathan Young.

Members of Anberlin originally formed a band under the name SaGoh 24/7 in 1998, releasing two [[studio album]]s before disbanding, with the members having a change in musical direction and name. Anberlin was formed in 2002; within a year of forming, they had signed with semi-independent record label [[Tooth & Nail Records]] and released their debut album, ''[[Blueprints for the Black Market]]''. In 2005, the band released their second album, ''[[Never Take Friendship Personal]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.toothandnail.com/artists/3/Anberlin/bio/|title=Anberlin Biography|publisher=Tooth & Nail|access-date=April 25, 2009}}</ref> The band's third album, ''[[Cities (Anberlin album)|Cities]]'', was released in 2007, and became their first album to reach the top 20 of the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]], selling 34,000 copies in its debut week.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/1054412/norah-stays-tight-at-no-1-amidst-slow-sales-week |title=Norah Stays Tight at No. 1 Amidst Slow Sales Week |work=Billboard |access-date=April 25, 2009}}</ref>

Anberlin signed with major label [[Universal Republic]] in 2007<ref name=univ/> and in 2008 released ''[[New Surrender]]'', which peaked at No. 13 on the Billboard 200,<ref name=albchart /> with the first single, "[[Feel Good Drag]]", claiming No. 1 on the [[Alternative Songs]] chart, after 29 weeks in the chart.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/charts/alternative-songs/2009-05-02|title=Hot Modern Rock Tracks - Feel Good Drag|work=Billboard|access-date=April 24, 2009}}</ref> Prior to the release of their fifth studio album, ''[[Dark Is the Way, Light Is a Place]]'', Anberlin had sold over 1,000,000 albums.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jesusfreakhideout.com/news/2014/01/17.TOOTH%20and%20NAIL%20RECORDS%20WELCOMES%20THE%20RETURN%20OF%20ANBERLIN.asp|title=Tooth and Nail Press Release|access-date=January 28, 2014}}</ref> Their sixth studio album ''[[Vital (Anberlin album)|Vital]]'' was released October 16, 2012, and rereleased on Big3 Records under the title ''[[Devotion (Anberlin album)|Devotion]]'' a year later, October 15, 2013.

On January 16, 2014, it was announced that Anberlin would be disbanding in 2014 after recording their seventh and then-final studio album, ''[[Lowborn]]'', on their original label, Tooth & Nail Records, and touring one last time.<ref name="2014Final">{{cite web|url=http://kroq.cbslocal.com/2014/01/17/anberlin-breaking-up-after-final-album-tour/ |title=Anberlin Breaking Up After Final Album & Tour |publisher=KROQ |date= January 17, 2014 |access-date=January 18, 2014}}</ref> After performing concerts in late 2018, the group reunited to tour through 2019. In May 2020, Christian mentioned they were working on new material.<ref name="Newmusic2020">{{cite web|url=https://notetoscene.com/anberlin-new-music-2020/ |title=Anberlin new music 2020 |publisher=Notetoscene |date= May 24, 2020 |access-date=July 25, 2020}}</ref>  Anberlin released their new EP ''[[Silverline]]'' on July 29, 2022.  This release breaks an 8 year  drought of new music from the band, and "showcases their expansive sound, ranging from full on rock anthems, to lighter post-rock inspired tracks."<ref>{{Cite web |date=July 29, 2022 |title=ANBERLIN RELEASE NEW EP, ‘SILVERLINE’ |url=https://www.equalvision.com/news/anberlin-release-new-ep-silverline/ |website=Equal Vision}}</ref>

==History==

===SaGoh 24/7 and the origins of Anberlin (1998–2002)===
Lead singer Stephen Christian met bassist Deon Rexroat while they were both in high school, and they formed a [[punk rock|punk]] band called SaGoh 24/7. Drummer Sean Hutson and guitarist Joseph Milligan joined the group as well. The band released two albums, ''Servants After God's Own Heart'' (1999), and ''Then I Corrupt Youth'' (2001), both under Rescue Records.<ref name=ow>{{cite web|url=http://orlandoweekly.com/music/story.asp?id=4746|title= Change the World|last=Perez|first=Omar|work= Orlando Weekly|date=July 24, 2003|access-date=July 19, 2004}}</ref> After the albums sold only 1,300 units,<ref name=Wander>{{cite web|url=http://www.anberlinfans.com/media/hm/02.jpg|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080805202141/http://www.anberlinfans.com/media/hm/02.jpg|url-status=dead|archive-date=August 5, 2008|title=Anberlin -- We the Wanderers}}</ref> Hutson left the band to start a family, and Nathan Young was brought in as a replacement.

Christian, Milligan and Rexroat began working on a side project, marking the beginning of the end for SaGoh 24/7. The side project's sound transformed after a suggestion from Milligan to develop more of a rock sound for Anberlin.<ref name=ow/> They used money left over from shows SaGoh had performed and teamed up with producer Matt Goldman to record five demos. The demos that were then posted on [[PureVolume]] (which was mp3.com at the time). On the advice of friends, including Chad Johnson, and Timmy McTague from [[Underoath]], the band signed with [[Tooth & Nail Records]].<ref name="Alternative Press Podcast No. 29"/>

===First two albums (2002–2005)===
[[File:AnberlinDeonRexroat.jpg|thumb|right|Bassist Deon Rexroat performing at Purple Door in August 2007]]
Out of the five demos Anberlin recorded with Matt Goldman, three were eventually chosen to be reworked for the band's debut album, the lead single "Readyfuels", "Driving" (later renamed "Autobahn") and "Foreign Language". Another song, "Embrace the Dead", was also recorded as a demo track and is often mistaken as an Anberlin song, however, the song didn't make it onto the band's debut album as it didn't constitute the stylistic direction the band wanted to head in.<ref name="Alternative Press Podcast No. 29"/>

After hearing demos from the band [[Acceptance (band)|Acceptance]], Anberlin chose to record their debut album with the same producer, Aaron Sprinkle, creating a relationship that would last the entire duration of their time with Tooth & Nail Records.<ref name="Alternative Press Podcast No. 29"/> Barely a year after their formation, their first album as a new band was entitled ''[[Blueprints for the Black Market]]'' (2003). It failed to chart, but spurred on by their debut single, "Readyfuels", the album sold over 60,000 units.<ref name=SPTNK>{{Cite web|url=https://www.sputnikmusic.com/review/61227/Anberlin-Never-Take-Friendship-Personal/|title=Anberlin - Never Take Friendship Personal (album review ) | Sputnikmusic|website=www.sputnikmusic.com}}</ref> They toured steadily with other bands in their label.{{Citation needed|date=May 2009}}

Rhythm guitarist Joey Bruce was eventually ejected from the band. According to Christian, he was "all about sex, drugs and rock & roll", and was going in a different direction than the rest of the band.<ref name=Wander/> After several failed replacements, Nathan Strayer from The Mosaic took over rhythm guitar duties.

Anberlin released their follow-up to ''Blueprints'', ''[[Never Take Friendship Personal]]'', in early 2005, again produced by Aaron Sprinkle. Charting at No. 144 on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]],<ref name=albchart>{{cite web|url={{BillboardURLbyName|artist=anberlin|chart=all}} |title=Artist Albums Charts History for: Anberlin |work=Billboard |access-date=August 11, 2008 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140810010315/http://www.billboard.com/artist/279033/anberlin/chart |archive-date=August 10, 2014 }}</ref> the album brought the band closer to the mainstream. ''NTFP'' was generally more well received by critics than ''Blueprints for the Black Market.''{{Citation needed|date=August 2008}} Before its release, the band promoted the album by releasing a track per week on their [[PureVolume]] and [[MySpace]] website accounts, as well as on their own website. Two singles were released from the album: "A Day Late" and "Paperthin Hymn". Both were reasonably successful on alternative rock radio, with the latter peaking at the No. 38 position on the [[Hot Modern Rock Tracks]] chart.<ref name=singlechart>{{cite web|url={{BillboardURLbyName|artist=anberlin|chart=all}}|title=Artist Singles Chart History for: Anberlin|work=Billboard|access-date=August 11, 2008}}</ref>

Anberlin participated in a number of compilations during this time, recording covers of [[Bob Dylan]]'s "[[Like a Rolling Stone]]", [[Depeche Mode]]'s "[[Enjoy the Silence]]," and the song "[[Christmas (Baby Please Come Home)]]".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/anberlin-mn0000749335/credits|title=Anberlin {{!}} Credits|publisher=AllMusic|access-date=November 19, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/happy-christmas-vol-4-mw0000170781|title=Happy Christmas, Vol. 4 - Various Artists {{!}} Songs, Reviews, Credits|publisher=AllMusic|access-date=November 19, 2019}}</ref>

===''Cities'' and ''Lost Songs'' (2005–2007)===
[[Image:Anberlin.jpg|thumb|upright|Performing in [[Las Cruces, NM]] at the 2007 Warped Tour]]Anberlin's third album produced by Aaron Sprinkle was released in early 2007 under the title ''[[Cities (Anberlin album)|Cities]]''. It sold 34,000 copies in its first week of release, debuted at No. 19 on the Billboard 200 chart, and, like their previous album, received fairly positive reviews from critics. Before the release of ''Cities'', the band released ''[[Godspeed EP]]'' exclusively through the [[iTunes Store]] in late 2006 to give a preview to the new album. In support of the album, Anberlin held their first headlining tour, supported by [[Bayside (band)|Bayside]], [[Meg & Dia]] and [[Jonezetta]].

In an interview about the album, Christian commented that the lyrics throughout the band's discography are progressively becoming more mature. "The first CD (''Blueprints for the Black Market'') was childish in the manner that it was Man vs. World in the lyrics. The second (''Never Take Friendship Personal'') was Man Vs. Man. ''Cities'' is more adult in the manner that it's Man Vs. Self.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.insidevandy.com/drupal/node/3434 |title=LIFE: Anberlin's "Cities" best album of 2007 so far |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071113170229/http://www.insidevandy.com/drupal/node/3434 |archive-date=November 13, 2007 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://live.hollywoodjesus.com/?p=229|title=Live with Stephen Christian and Nathan Strayer}}</ref> ''Cities'' was the most anticipated album on Jesus Freak Hideout's Most Anticipated Albums of 2007.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.jesusfreakhideout.com/features/highlights/2007/Anberlin.asp |title = Jesus Freak Hideout's 25 Most Anticipated Albums of 2007. |access-date =November 14, 2008 |publisher = JesusFreakHideout.com| archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20081206010540/http://www.jesusfreakhideout.com/features/highlights/2007/Anberlin.asp| archive-date= December 6, 2008 | url-status= live}}</ref>

Three to four weeks before the release of ''Cities'', it was announced that guitarist Nathan Strayer amicably left the band to go back to the Mosaic and that Christian McAlhaney, formerly of the band [[Acceptance (band)|Acceptance]], would take over as the new guitarist.<ref>Kohli, Rohan. {{cite web |url = http://www.absolutepunk.net/showthread.php?t=214135 |title = Anberlin Parts Ways With Guitarist |access-date =May 1, 2007 |date = February 19, 2007 |website = AbsolutePunk}}</ref>

A [[compilation album]] of unreleased material, called ''[[Lost Songs (Anberlin album)|Lost Songs]]'', was released on November 20, 2007. It features [[B-sides]], [[Demo (music)|demos]], [[Cover version|covers]], and [[Acoustic music|acoustic]] versions of their previous songs as well as other tracks recorded at [[Sessions@AOL]].<ref name="livelostsongs">{{cite web|url=http://www.livedaily.com/news/13260.html |title=Anberlin finds 'Lost Songs' on the road |access-date=May 20, 2008 |date=November 28, 2008 |work=Live Daily |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080217013805/http://www.livedaily.com/news/13260.html |archive-date=February 17, 2008 }}</ref>

===Universal Republic signing and ''New Surrender'' (2007–2009)===
[[Image:Anberlin Commodore.jpg|thumb|upright|Performing at the [[Commodore Ballroom]] in May 2009]]The band signed to [[Universal Republic]] on August 16, 2007, and soon after began to write material for their major-label debut, entitled ''[[New Surrender]]'', which was released on September 30, 2008.<ref name=univ>{{cite web |url = http://www.absolutepunk.net/showthread.php?t=321717 |title = AbsolutePunk |access-date =May 29, 2008 |website = AbsolutePunk| archive-url= https://archive.today/2008.05.30-175952/http://www.absolutepunk.net/showthread.php?t=321717| archive-date= May 30, 2008 | url-status= live}}</ref> This was the band's first album to not be distributed through [[Tooth & Nail Records]] or produced by Aaron Sprinkle. The first song to be heard from the new album was tentatively titled "Bittersweet Memory" during its initial live performances; it was later renamed to "Breaking", with an acoustic remix of the song included on USB wristbands sold exclusively during the 2008 Warped Tour. On July 11, 2008, the band showcased a second new song called "Disappear" on their [[MySpace]] profile.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.get2sammyb.co.uk/594/disappear-by-anberlin-revealed-on-myspace/ |title=Anberlin Showcase New Song Disappear From Album New Surrender |access-date=July 11, 2008 |date=July 11, 2008 |publisher=get2sammyb.co.uk |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081006211829/http://www.get2sammyb.co.uk/594/disappear-by-anberlin-revealed-on-myspace/ |archive-date=October 6, 2008 }}</ref> The first actual single from the album was the re-recorded "[[Feel Good Drag]]" which was set to go to radio on August 18<ref name=feelgooddrag>{{cite web |url = http://absolutepunk.net/showthread.php?t=416761 |title = Radio date for new Anberlin single |date= July 18, 2008 |access-date =July 19, 2008 |website = AbsolutePunk| archive-url= https://archive.today/2008.07.26-001801/http://www.absolutepunk.net/showthread.php?t=416761| archive-date= July 26, 2008 | url-status= live}}</ref> - eventually being released on August 26.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.absolutepunk.net/showthread.php?t=494381|title=Feel Good About Helping Anberlin|website=AbsolutePunk|access-date=January 9, 2009}}</ref>

The band booked eight weeks of recording sessions with noted producer Neal Avron ([[New Found Glory]], [[Yellowcard]], [[Fall Out Boy]]) in early February 2008. Stephen Christian stated in an interview, "We're very excited about working with Neal; I think our fans are going to be pleased when they hear the final result."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ultimate-guitar.com/news/press_releases/anberlin_hit_studio_for_universal_republic_debut.html |title=Anberlin Hit Studio for Universal Republic Debut |access-date=January 18, 2007 |date=January 15, 2008 |publisher=Ultimate-Guitar.com |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080120104607/http://www.ultimate-guitar.com/news/press_releases/anberlin_hit_studio_for_universal_republic_debut.html |archive-date=January 20, 2008 }}</ref> Christian also discussed the difficulties in writing this record. "When you try to write 29 songs lyrically you find yourself topically working in circles; I only go through so much in one year, but needlessly I have dedicated myself to begin searching books, art, and friends for new directions."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.drivenfaroff.com/2008/02/12/anberlin-post-studio-update/|title=Anberlin post studio update |date= February 12, 2008 |publisher=drivenfaroff.com}}</ref>  During the recording process, the band set up a live webcam in the studio so fans could watch them record the album via the band's MySpace profile.  ''New Surrender'' was placed at the No. 2 spot on Jesus Freak Hideout's 25 Most Anticipated Albums of 2008.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.jesusfreakhideout.com/features/highlights/2008/Anberlin.asp |title = Jesus Freak Hideout's 25 Most Anticipated Albums of 2008. |access-date =February 1, 2008 |publisher = JesusFreakHideout.com| archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20080129090701/http://www.jesusfreakhideout.com/features/highlights/2008/Anberlin.asp| archive-date= January 29, 2008 | url-status= live}}</ref>

In the week of its release, the album sold 36,000 units, entering the ''Billboard'' 200 chart at No. 13.<ref name="Billboard New Surrender">{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/1043841/ti-debuts-big-atop-billboard-200-hot-100|title=T.I. Debuts Big Atop Billboard 200, Hot 100|work=Billboard|last=Hasty|first=Katie|date=October 8, 2008|access-date=October 8, 2008| archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20081009081131/http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/1043841/ti-debuts-big-atop-billboard-200-hot-100| archive-date= October 9, 2008 | url-status= live}}</ref> It also placed at No. 5 on the Top Current Rock chart, according to a Universal Republic press release.<ref name="MarketWatch">{{cite web|url=http://www.marketwatch.com/news/story/anberlin-debuts-13-billboard-top/story.aspx?guid={14845DC7-8BDD-4472-A3AA-F57D801E8253}&dist=hppr|title=Anberlin Debuts at No. 13 on Billboard Top 200 and No. 5 on Top Current Rock Chart with New Surrender|website=MarketWatch|date=October 8, 2008|access-date=October 8, 2008}}</ref> In support of the album, the band embarked on a fall headlining U.S. tour alongside [[Scary Kids Scaring Kids]], [[Straylight Run]], and [[There For Tomorrow]]. Kyle Flynn, formerly of the band Acceptance, joined the band while on tour doing keys, loops, acoustic guitar, and background vocals.  The band then traveled to the United Kingdom where they supported [[Elliot Minor]] and played a handful of headlining shows with [[Furthest Drive Home]] and Data.Select.Party.

Anberlin went into the studio to record several tracks, including a cover of the [[New Order (band)|New Order]] song "[[True Faith (song)|True Faith]]", which was made available online. The band also recorded a cover of the [[Danzig (band)|Danzig]] song "[[Mother (Danzig song)|Mother]]", which they performed during an interview with ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/267894/video-anberlin-does-danzig-talks-surrender|title=Video: Anberlin Does Danzig, Talks "Surrender"|work=Billboard|access-date=August 2, 2009}}</ref> After supporting [[Taking Back Sunday]] throughout May and June 2009, the band planned to start writing the follow-up to ''New Surrender'' in the summer, but the release date was undetermined, as the band needed to give the new material the proper time and effort.<ref name="rocksound">{{cite web|url=http://www.rocksound.tv/tv/interview/anberlin|title=TV > Interviews > Anberlin (video)|publisher=Rock Sound TV|access-date=December 30, 2008}}</ref> They also undertook an Australian tour in August, alongside [[The Academy Is...]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.altpress.com/news/7084.htm |title=Anberlin to tour Australia with The Academy Is... |work=[[Alternative Press (music magazine)|Alternative Press]] |access-date=June 1, 2009 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090603082227/http://www.altpress.com/news/7084.htm |archive-date=June 3, 2009 |url-status=dead  }}</ref> A b-side from ''New Surrender'', "A Perfect Tourniquet", was released on the [[Soundtrack 90210|soundtrack]] for the TV show ''[[90210 (TV series)|90210]]''. The cover of New Order's "True Faith" was released to radio airplay on November 17,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.absolutepunk.net/showthread.php?t=1410231 |title=Anberlin Cover Hitting Radio - News Article |publisher=AbsolutePunk.net |access-date=July 6, 2010}}</ref> the same day as the Tooth & Nail released ''Blueprints for City Friendships: The Anberlin Anthology'', which is a 33-song, three-album set including all the songs from their Tooth & Nail studio albums.

===''Dark Is the Way, Light Is a Place'' (2010–2011)===
In an interview with the ''[[South Florida Sun-Sentinel]]'' in December 2009, it was revealed by lead singer Stephen Christian that the band were tentatively due to enter the studio in the beginning of 2010, with a release probable later in the year. He said "it looks like we are going to go to the studio in January, February or March, right around that time".<ref name="Sun-Sentinel interview with Stephen">{{cite web|url=http://www.sun-sentinel.com/entertainment/music/sfl-anberlin-buzz-bake-sale-1203,0,7669057.story |title=Q & A with Anberlin: Central Florida band plays Buzz Bake sale Dec. 5 |date=December 3, 2009 |author=Mike Rothman |work=South Florida Sun-Sentinel |access-date=December 9, 2009 }}{{dead link|date=May 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Drummer Nathan Young stated that the album would be "less poppy" and "darker".<ref name="Stardust Interview">{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gMwSzHlNR6I |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211212/gMwSzHlNR6I| archive-date=2021-12-12 |url-status=live|title=Interview with Nate and Christian of Anberlin|date=June 21, 2009|publisher=Stardust|access-date=December 9, 2009}}{{cbignore}}</ref> Christian posted on his [[Twitter]] account in December 2009, that his choice for an album name was "a go" but did not reveal the name.<ref name="Anberlin chose new album title">{{cite web|url=http://www.absolutepunk.net/showthread.php?t=1455322|title=Anberlin News|publisher=Absolute Punk|access-date=December 9, 2009| archive-url= https://archive.today/2009.12.15-074627/http://www.absolutepunk.net/showthread.php?t=1455322| archive-date= December 15, 2009 | url-status= live}}</ref>

The band entered Blackbird Studios, Nashville, to begin recording the album in March 2010.<ref name="studio">{{cite web|url=http://www.absolutepunk.net/artists/showlink.php?do=showdetails&l=1751|title=Anberlin Begin Recording|website=AbsolutePunk|access-date=March 4, 2010| archive-url= https://archive.today/2010.03.02-213016/http://www.absolutepunk.net/artists/showlink.php?do=showdetails&l=1751| archive-date= March 2, 2010 | url-status= live}}</ref> It was announced on March 3 that the band would be working with Grammy Award-winning producer, [[Brendan O'Brien (music producer)|Brendan O'Brien]].<ref name="O'Brien announcement">{{cite web|url=http://www.absolutepunk.net/showthread.php?t=1580822|title=Anberlin Announce Producer|website=AbsolutePunk|access-date=March 4, 2010}}</ref> The tracking of the album was completed on April 9,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.absolutepunk.net/showthread.php?t=1638702|title=Something Close To Cities Please|publisher=Absolute Punk|access-date=April 19, 2010| archive-url= https://archive.today/2010.04.14-135534/http://www.absolutepunk.net/showthread.php?t=1638702| archive-date= April 14, 2010 | url-status= live}}</ref> with mixing commencing on April 13, 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.absolutepunk.net/showthread.php?t=1643072|title=Anberlin Mixing|publisher=Absolute Punk|access-date=April 19, 2010}}</ref> In an April 2010 interview with MyMag, Christian stated that the album's release date is "looking like late July or early August" 2010.<ref name="mymag">{{cite web|url=http://www.myyearbook.com/?mysession=bWFnX2FydGljbGVfcmVhZCZh%20aWQ9MzQ0OTg=|title= Stephen Christian Talks Anberlin and Faceless International|publisher=MyYearbook. MyMag|access-date=April 19, 2010}}</ref> However, in a May 2010 interview with Spin Magazine, McAlhaney stated that the album would be released in September 2010.<ref name="SpinInterview">{{cite web|url=http://www.spin.com/articles/watch-mastodon-rob-zombie-anberlin|title= WATCH:Mastodon, Rob Zombie, Anberlin Spin Magazine Online|date= May 24, 2010|publisher=SPIN Magazine. SpinInterview|access-date=May 31, 2010| archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20100527064237/http://www.spin.com/articles/watch-mastodon-rob-zombie-anberlin| archive-date= May 27, 2010 | url-status= live}}</ref>

In early June 2010, the album's release date was confirmed to be September 21, 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.absolutepunk.net/showthread.php?t=1732302|title=New Anberlin in September|publisher=Absolute Punk|access-date=July 3, 2010}}</ref> The band also began exposing their new music, with videos of live performances of the album's songs appearing online.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.absolutepunk.net/showthread.php?t=1736032|title=New Anberlin Tune|publisher=Absolute Punk|access-date=July 3, 2010}}</ref> A press release revealed on June 17 that Anberlin's fifth studio album would be titled ''[[Dark Is the Way, Light Is a Place]]'', taking its title from a line in [[Dylan Thomas]]’ "Poem on His Birthday". Along with the disclosure of a track listing, the press release also announced the album's lead single, "Impossible",<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.absolutepunk.net/showthread.php?t=1754742|title=Anberlin Press Release|publisher=Absolute Punk|access-date=July 3, 2010| archive-url= https://archive.today/2010.06.24-151444/http://www.absolutepunk.net/showthread.php?t=1754742| archive-date= June 24, 2010 | url-status= live}}</ref> which went to radio play on July 12, 2010.<ref name="'Impossible' goes to radio">{{cite magazine|url=http://fmqb.com/Article.asp?id=16770|title=First Single From New Album Hits Radio In July|magazine=FMQB|access-date=March 6, 2010| archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20100325040728/http://www.fmqb.com/article.asp?id=16770| archive-date= March 25, 2010 | url-status= live}}</ref>

When asked about the possible impact of the new album, Stephen replied 'I feel like we're on the brink of something... either world domination or destruction, but either way we're on the brink'.<ref name="'Q&A's with Stephen">{{cite web|url=http://chatter.myyearbook.com/askMe/ask/27588676|title=Stephen Answers Questions|publisher=myyearbook.com|access-date=April 6, 2010}}</ref>

Anberlin supported [[Thirty Seconds to Mars]] on their [[Into the Wild Tour|Closer to the Edge Tour]] with CB7 during April and May 2011.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.capitolstreetteam.com/news.php?show=show_story&news_id=70851750|title=Anberlin and CB7 Join Closer to the Edge Tour|publisher=[[Capitol Music Group]]|date=March 21, 2011|access-date=March 22, 2011}}</ref>

===''Vital'' and ''Devotion'' (2012–2013)===
In an interview with ''Common Revolt'', Stephen Christian stated that the band had begun work on their next album. A few songs had been written, including one with the working title "Control" (later renamed Orpheum), and a song influenced by the events in Egypt <ref name="Common Revolt">{{cite news|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Jf70GK_Wbys |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211212/Jf70GK_Wbys| archive-date=2021-12-12 |url-status=live|title=Stephen Christian Interview May 2011|publisher=Common Revolt|date=May 10, 2011|access-date=May 10, 2011}}{{cbignore}}</ref> (later confirmed to be "Someone Anyone").<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fuse.tv/videos/2012/11/anberlin-egyptian-uprising-inspiration-interview |title=Anberlin On How the Egyptian Uprising Inspired 'Someone Anyone' - Video News - Fuse |publisher=Fuse.tv |date=November 27, 2012 |access-date=May 17, 2014}}</ref>

The band announced via Facebook and e-mail in February 2012 that they would be returning to [[Aaron Sprinkle]] to record their upcoming album.{{Citation needed|date=February 2012}} The band recorded their first three albums with Sprinkle; not only is he a good friend of the band but also a fan favorite. The band will begin recording around the start of March, and are not expected to be finished until May.<ref>{{Twitter|url=https://twitter.com/stephenanberlin/status/171018120918601729|title=Recording Till May|access-date=February 19, 2012}}</ref>{{Primary source inline|date=November 2019}} In a recent interview, Stephen Christian announced their new album is finally done.<ref name="Common Revolt"/> On June 11, during the Nashville show of their acoustic tour, Stephen Christian announced that the title of the new record would be [[Vital (Anberlin album)|''Vital'']], calling the record "their most aggressive to date" and also announced a fall release date.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.absolutepunk.net/showthread.php?t=2784532 |title=Anberlin - Vital (2012) |publisher=AbsolutePunk.net |access-date=August 30, 2012}}</ref> On July 31, the band announced on their official website that ''Vital'' was to be released on October 16.<ref>{{cite web|last=Ableson |first=Jon |url=http://www.alterthepress.com/2012/07/anberlin-announce-new-album-vital.html |title=Anberlin Announce New Album "Vital" Release Date |publisher=Alter The Press! |date=August 20, 2009 |access-date=May 17, 2014}}</ref>

The new album's opening track, "Self-Starter",' was streamed on Billboard.com for free listening on August 17.,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/480389/anberlins-self-starter-exclusive-first-listen |title=Anberlin's 'Self-Starter': Exclusive First Listen |work=Billboard |date=August 17, 2012 |access-date=May 17, 2014}}</ref> and the album's second single, "Someone Anyone" was released on August 22.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/anberlin/status/238304754952974337 |title=Twitter / anberlin: NEW JAM! Someone Anyone. Check |publisher=Twitter |date=August 22, 2012 |access-date=May 17, 2014}}</ref>{{Primary source inline|date=November 2019}}

''Infectious'' Magazine reported on October 26, 2012 that the band had already "made a lot of headway writing for the next record".<ref>{{cite web|author=Interview: Anberlin October 26, 2012 Angela Mastrogiacomo 0 |url=http://www.infectiousmagazine.com/interview-anberlin/ |title=Interview: Anberlin |work=Infectious Magazine |date=October 26, 2012 |access-date=September 20, 2013}}</ref>

The band released "[[City Electric]]" on September 20, 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/gb/album/city-electric-single/id696867071 |title=iTunes Music - City Electric - Single by Anberlin |publisher=iTunes Store |date=September 24, 2013 |access-date=January 16, 2014}}</ref> It is the first of three new and previously unreleased tracks from their rework of ''Vital'', ''[[Devotion (Anberlin album)|Devotion]]'' which was released on October 15, 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/gb/album/devotion/id710184935 |title=iTunes Music - Devotion by Anberlin |publisher=iTunes Store |date=October 15, 2013 |access-date=January 16, 2014}}</ref>

=== Return to Tooth & Nail, ''Lowborn'' and breakup (2014) ===

On the January 16, 2014, the band posted a video in which the band confirmed that this year would be their last and that they would release their seventh, and final, studio album in mid-2014 on their original label, Tooth & Nail Records. They also stated that they would do their last set of tours this year to celebrate what the band has become.<ref name="2014Final" /> On May 6, 2014, Anberlin revealed the title of the album, ''[[Lowborn]]'', as well as the album artwork.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.anberlin.com/main/final-album-final-tour/ |title=Final Album, Final Tour |publisher=Anberlin |date=May 6, 2014 |access-date=May 17, 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140515023317/http://www.anberlin.com/main/final-album-final-tour/ |archive-date=May 15, 2014 |url-status=dead  }}</ref> The band played their final show on November 26, 2014, at the [[House of Blues]] in Orlando, Florida.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.altpress.com/news/entry/anberlin_announce_another_batch_of_farewell_tour_dates_including_their_last|title=Anberlin announce another batch of farewell tour dates, including their last show ever - News - Alternative Press|website=Alternative Press|date=July 7, 2014|access-date=July 10, 2017}}</ref>

On December 15, 2017, it was announced that the band's former rhythm guitarist Nathan Strayer had died.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.crossrhythms.co.uk/articles/news/Nathan_Passes/61783/p1/|title=Nathan Passes: Former rhythm guitarist with Anberlin, Nathan Strayer dies|website=Crossrhythms.co.uk|access-date=December 22, 2017}}</ref> He was 34.<ref>[https://www.cltampa.com/music/music-news/article/20987130/year-in-review-the-ones-we-lost Year In Review: The ones we lost] access-date July 22, 2018</ref>

===Reunions, Equal Vision signing and upcoming eighth album (2018–present)===

On October 18, 2018, the band announced that they would reunite for one show on December 14 at the [[Yuengling Center]] in [[Tampa, Florida]], as part of [[Underoath]]'s Erase Me Tour.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.altpress.com/news/anberlin-reunion-underoath-show/|title=Anberlin to Reunite for Underoath Hometown Show|work=Alternative Press|date=October 18, 2018|access-date=October 19, 2018}}</ref> However, in March 2019, it was announced that the band would perform a series of headlining shows across Australia in May 2019.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Langford |first1=Jackson |title=Anberlin Announce 2019 Australian Tour |url=https://musicfeeds.com.au/news/anberlin-announce-2019-australian-tour/ |website=Music Feeds  |date=March 12, 2019 |access-date=March 13, 2019}}</ref> This expanded to an announcement of a 22-stop U.S. tour the following month.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Campbell |first1=Rachel|title=ANBERLIN ANNOUNCE FIRST TOUR IN FIVE YEARS |url=https://www.altpress.com/news/anberlin-tour-summer-2019-reunion/ |website=Alternative Press |date=April 9, 2019|publisher=ALTERNATIVE PRESS MAGAZINE |access-date=April 9, 2019}}</ref> Young stated the band had no plans for a full comeback after the reunion shows.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://wallofsoundau.com/2019/04/17/dont-expect-anberlin-to-make-a-comeback-after-their-reunion-shows/|title=Don't expect Anberlin to make a comeback after their reunion shows|last=brownypaul|date=April 16, 2019|website=Wall Of Sound|access-date=April 16, 2019}}</ref> However, Christian revealed in May 2020 that they had reversed course and were in the process of recording new music.<ref name="Newmusic2020"/>

{{citation needed span|On September 2, 2021, the band released their first new song in over seven years, "Two Graves" on their Youtube channel|reason=not realy that important, but it should still be sourced if included|date=December 2021}}, and {{citation needed span|began touring two days later, September 4|reason=the tour should be easy to source|date=December 2021}}, to promote the song.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2021-09-06 |title=Anberlin Returns With 2021 Single, 'Two Graves' |url=https://hmmagazine.com/anberlin-returns-with-2021-single-two-graves/ |access-date=2022-07-26 |website=HM Magazine |language=en}}</ref>

Anberlin released an EP, ''Silverline'', on July 29, 2022 via [[Equal Vision Records]],<ref>[http://www.equalvision.com/news/anberlin-sign-to-evr-and-announce-new-ep-silverline/ ANBERLIN SIGN TO EVR AND ANNOUNCE NEW EP, 'SILVERLINE']</ref> with whom they signed earlier in the month.

==Origin of name==
<!-- BEFORE REVERTING OR CONTRIBUTING TO THIS SECTION, PLEASE DISCUSS IN THE TALK PAGE -->
Anberlin lead vocalist Stephen Christian has stated different origins of the band's name in various interviews, prevalent among which was his claim that he had long intended to name his first daughter Anberlin. Struggling to find a name for the band, Stephen suggested it; "We were all sitting around trying to come up with a name. None of us were married or had kids, but one day I was going to name my daughter Anberlin, so I figured we could name the band that until we thought of something better. So we chose Anberlin and no one has thought of anything better."<ref name="Anberlin Aren't Christian Rock">{{cite web|url=http://www.chartattack.com/news/41560/anberlin-arent-christian-rock-but-its-ok-if-you-call-them-that |title=Anberlin Aren't Christian Rock, But It's OK If You Call Them That |access-date=November 17, 2008 |date=July 12, 2006 |work=[[Chart (magazine)|Chart]] |first=Scott |last=Bryson |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081206005126/http://www.chartattack.com/news/41560/anberlin-arent-christian-rock-but-its-ok-if-you-call-them-that |archive-date=December 6, 2008 |url-status=dead }}</ref> He stated he was no longer going to use Anberlin to name his first daughter, however he said, "If I ever have a daughter and name her Anberlin, she'll think she was named after the band instead of the other way around."<ref>Stavrinos, Nicole. {{cite web|url=http://hub.lsj.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20061011/NOISE02/610110302/1145 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070705184002/http://hub.lsj.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=%2F20061011%2FNOISE02%2F610110302%2F1145 |url-status=dead |archive-date=July 5, 2007 |title=Music: Anberlin |access-date=May 1, 2007 |date=October 11, 2006 |publisher=NOISE }}</ref> Christian had also stated in another interview that the band's name was created when he was thinking about cities in Europe he wanted to visit. In his mind he listed "London, Paris, Rome, and [[Berlin]]." Christian thought that "and Berlin" would be an appropriate name for a band, and so when the band was looking for a name Christian suggested "And Berlin," which was then modified to "Anberlin."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.europunk.net/interviews.php?id=45 |title=Interview With Anberlin |access-date=May 1, 2007 |date=June 3, 2003 |publisher=Europunk.net |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070325230727/http://www.europunk.net/interviews.php?id=45 |archive-date=March 25, 2007 |url-status=live  }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.hmmagazine.com/exclusive/anberlin_interview_sept_2003200308/index.php |access-date=August 10, 2008 |work=[[HM (magazine)|HM]] |date=September 2003 |title=Anberlin - Interview, Sept. 2003 |first=Jessica |last=McCrae |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081206034243/http://www.hmmagazine.com/exclusive/anberlin_interview_sept_2003200308/index.php |archive-date=December 6, 2008 }}</ref>

Christian has since retracted those comments admitting that when the band first started, in interviews they "would take turn making stories about how it came to be" as a joke, as he believed the actual origin of the band name wasn't interesting enough. Christian said there was a story about how his grandfather had "saved a little girl from a [[World War II]] bombing... her name was Anberlin" and that they had hit a dog, which had the name Anberlin, with the stories getting more diverse, it was decided they reveal the true origin.<ref name=walmartwarped>{{cite web|url=http://soundcheck.walmart.com/warped.html|title=Anberlin interview|publisher=Soundcheck.Walmart.com|access-date=August 18, 2008| archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20080828125958/http://soundcheck.walmart.com/warped.html| archive-date= August 28, 2008 | url-status= live}}</ref> He has said the "real" name came from the [[Radiohead]] song "[[Everything in Its Right Place]]", stating that "There are several stories that have circulated on the internet, but the actual story is when I was in college my favorite band was Radiohead; on one of their songs off the record ''[[Kid A]]'' there is a background noise on the song "Everything in Its Right Place" (about 2 minutes 31 seconds into the song). While [[Thom Yorke|Thom (Yorke)]] is singing ''try to say'' I always thought the background noise sounded like ''Anberlin'', I always thought that Anberlin would have been a great band name and well...it was/is."<ref name="Sun-Sentinel interview with Stephen"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.beatthescene.com/interviews/anberlin.html |title=Anberlin |publisher=BeatTheScene.com |access-date=August 11, 2008 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080801132318/http://www.beatthescene.com/interviews/anberlin.html |archive-date=August 1, 2008 |url-status=dead }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.new-noise.net/features/features/anberlin_2766.html |title=Anberlin |publisher=New-Noise.net |first=Laila |last=Hassani |date=September 23, 2007 |access-date=August 10, 2008 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071015141959/http://www.new-noise.net/features/features/anberlin_2766.html |archive-date=October 15, 2007 }}</ref>

==Christianity==
Over the years, many fans, critics, and other members of the media have consistently characterized Anberlin as a [[Christian rock|Christian]] band. However, Stephen Christian stated in an interview that their faith is more complicated than a simple label: "I think we're categorized like that a lot because we're on [[Tooth & Nail Records]], which, years ago, was known as a Christian label and never lost that reputation. I don't care who listens to our records. If it helps people in whatever circumstances they're in, that's amazing, but I definitely don't classify us as a Christian band."<ref name="Anberlin Aren't Christian Rock"/> Elsewhere, Christian has remarked, "[My faith] affects every single aspect of my life, but I'm not a preacher, I'm an entertainer."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thisweeknews.com/?sec=home&story=sites/thisweeknews/042607/common/News/042607-News-345223.html| title= Florida-based band Anberlin to play the Basement May 1| publisher= ThisWeek Community Newspapers| date= April 26, 2007|access-date=January 13, 2009}}</ref>

Despite these statements and others of the like, multiple sources list the band as part of the Christian rock genre, and some Anberlin song lyrics do contain Christian references. Furthermore, the band appears at Christian music festivals such as [[Parachute Music Festival]] and [[Cornerstone Festival]], and their songs have been included on Christian rock compilation CDs<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://musicmoz.org/Releases/Compilations/X/X_2003-_Experience_The_Alternative/|title=MusicMoz - Releases: Compilations: X: X 2003- Experience The Alternative|website=musicmoz.org}}</ref> and DVDs.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/dp/B000I2ISE0|title=Amazon -- X 2007}}</ref>  They are also played on the [[Gospel Music Channel]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gospelmusicchannel.com/artists/detail/anberlin |title=Anberlin | Christian Music - Gospel Music Channel |publisher=Gospelmusicchannel.com |access-date=October 27, 2008 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080828193938/http://gospelmusicchannel.com/artists/detail/anberlin |archive-date=August 28, 2008 |url-status=live  }}</ref>

Anberlin has also been repeatedly featured in Christian rock magazine ''HM'' (''Hard Music'', which was originally the fanzine ''Heaven's Metal''). Christian submitted a letter to the magazine, criticizing the more overtly religious [[Christian punk]] band the [[Knights of the New Crusade]] for a promotional image that represented a "black mark on the face of Christianity".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hmmagazine.com/exclusive/anberlins_stephen_goes_off200503/index.php |title=Anberlin's Stephen Goes Off|publisher=HM Letters to the Editor, HM Online Exclusives|access-date=January 5, 2009| archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20090129195459/http://hmmagazine.com/exclusive/anberlins_stephen_goes_off200503/index.php| archive-date= January 29, 2009 | url-status= live}}</ref>

Christian has also said in an interview with Lightforce radio how the band tries to "step out of the bubble" and referred to themselves as being part of Christian music. He discussed in detail what Christians should do in their lives: love and embrace others as [[Jesus]] would as well as show God's grace to others. He mentioned as well how the band [[Fall Out Boy]] said in an interview that they did not really know much about Jesus until Anberlin toured with them.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://web.thejoyfm.com/cruise/lightforce/steveninterview.mp3|title=The Joy FM Radio Interview}}</ref>

In an interview with Smartpunk, drummer Nathan Young commented, "The thing is, some bands that are trying to get out of the Christian market, they get bummed out by questions about it. I don’t really mind it, because I’m a Christian, and I’m okay talking about it. With the whole term 'Christian Band,' I don’t understand how a band can be Christian. We get the question, 'Is Anberlin a Christian band?' and it’s like, yeah, Anberlin is — as humans".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.smartpunk.com/smartpick/ |title=Smartpick of the Month - Anberlin |publisher=Smartpunk |access-date=September 9, 2008 |archive-date=October 6, 2008 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081006084619/http://www.smartpunk.com/smartpick/ |url-status=dead  }}</ref>

==Side projects==
=== Anchor & Braille ===
{{main|Anchor & Braille}}
Stephen Christian formed an [[acoustic music|acoustic]] side project, [[Anchor & Braille]]. The project was originally a joint venture with [[Aaron Marsh]] of the band [[Copeland (band)|Copeland]]; however, Marsh did not feature on the project's debut album, entitled ''[[Felt (Anchor & Braille album)|Felt]]'', although he did produce it.<ref name="Alternative Press Podcast No. 29">{{cite web|url=http://media.altpress.com/specials/podcasts/AP_Podcast_29_ANBERLIN.m4a? |title=Anberlin Podcast with Alternative Press Magazine |access-date=December 2, 2008 |date=November 2008 |work=[[Alternative Press (music magazine)|Alternative Press]] |first=Mike |last=Shea }}{{dead link|date=May 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> The project first yielded a 7" vinyl, and ''Felt'' was released on August 4, 2009.<ref name="Abs">{{cite web|url=http://www.absolutepunk.net/showthread.php?t=1104822|title=Anchor & Braille Release Date, Track List|website=AbsolutePunk|access-date=June 18, 2009}}</ref> On July 31, 2012, Anchor & Braille's second album, ''[[The Quiet Life]]'', was released. Later, in 2016, after the break-up of Anberlin, Anchor & Braille's third studio album, ''[[Songs for the Late Night Drive Home]]'', was released.

=== Carrollhood ===

Nathan Young formed a side project with his brother-in-law Tim McTague of [[Underoath]] and Reed Murray in July 2011.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.altpress.com/news/underoath_anberlin_say_anything_members_perform_first_show_as_carrollhood/|title=Underoath, Anberlin, Say Anything members perform first show as Carrollhood|date=March 6, 2016|website=Alternative Press}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.soundlinkmagazine.com/carrollhood-underoaths-tim-mctague-new-album/|title=Carrollhood (Tim McTague of Underoath) Announce New Album|date=January 11, 2018|website=Soundlink Magazine}}</ref> Carrollhood released their first three-song EP, ''Afraid'', on August 23, 2012. The EP included "Afraid", "Remission" and "Mr. Tampa". The second three-song EP, ''Violence'', was released February 11, 2013. It included "Two Minutes Hate", "Violence", "MDSFWL".

=== Sins ===

Joseph Milligan formed a side project, "Sins", who released ''Sink Away'' on December 19, 2012.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://underthegunreview.net/2015/05/29/sins-joseph-milligan-of-anberlin-streams-new-album-divider/|title=Sins (Joseph Milligan of Anberlin) Streams New Album, 'Divider' {{!}} Under the Gun Review|last=Florence|first=Kyle}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.altpress.com/news/anberlin_guitarist_releases_new_album_for_sins_project/|title=Anberlin guitarist releases new album for Sins project|last=AltPress|date=May 29, 2015|website=Alternative Press}}</ref>

=== Loose Talk ===

Former Anberlin members Deon Rexroat and Christian McAlhaney started a band called Loose Talk. Former drummer Nathan Young provided the drums for the band's first EP.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://loosetalkisnoosetalk.com/|title=EP, by LOOSE TALK|website=LOOSE TALK|access-date=July 7, 2016}}</ref>
